title: Heart Failure Management
description: A comprehensive care plan for patients with heart failure, focusing on symptom management, fluid balance, and improving quality of life.

assessments.title: Vital Signs
points: Monitor blood pressure, heart rate, and respiratory rate q4h and PRN
Assess for orthostatic hypotension when changing positions
Monitor oxygen saturation continuously or q4h
Monitor temperature q8h and PRN
assessments.description: Vital sign monitoring helps detect early signs of decompensation and evaluate response to therapy

assessments.title: Cardiovascular Assessment
points: Assess for presence of S3 heart sound (ventricular gallop)
Auscultate lungs for crackles or rales
Assess for jugular venous distention
Evaluate peripheral pulses and capillary refill
Monitor for chest pain or discomfort
assessments.description: Comprehensive cardiac assessment to evaluate heart failure status and identify complications

assessments.title: Fluid Status
points: Measure daily weight at same time each day
Maintain strict intake and output records
Assess for peripheral edema and document degree (1+ to 4+)
Measure abdominal girth if ascites present
Monitor for signs of pulmonary edema
assessments.description: Fluid status assessment is critical for managing heart failure and preventing complications

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Decreased Cardiac Output related to altered contractility as evidenced by fatigue, dyspnea, and edema
Excess Fluid Volume related to compromised regulatory mechanisms as evidenced by edema, weight gain, and crackles

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved cardiac output as evidenced by stable vital signs and decreased symptoms of heart failure
indicators: Heart rate between 60-100 bpm
Blood pressure within patient's normal range
Respiratory rate 12-20/min
Oxygen saturation >92%
Decreased fatigue with activity

goals.statement: Patient will maintain optimal fluid balance as evidenced by stable weight and decreased edema
indicators: Weight within 2 kg of baseline
Balanced intake and output
Reduction in peripheral edema
Absence of crackles on lung auscultation
Normal jugular venous pressure

interventions.title: Cardiac Care
actions: Administer cardiac medications as prescribed (ACE inhibitors, beta-blockers, diuretics)
Position patient in semi-Fowler's or high Fowler's position to decrease cardiac workload
Implement progressive activity plan based on tolerance
Monitor for signs of digoxin toxicity if applicable
Educate on energy conservation techniques
rationales: Medications improve cardiac function and reduce symptoms
Upright positioning reduces cardiac workload and improves ventilation
Gradual activity prevents deconditioning while avoiding cardiac strain
Early detection of digoxin toxicity prevents serious complications
Energy conservation reduces cardiac demands
interventions.frequency: Ongoing throughout hospitalization

interventions.title: Fluid Management
actions: Administer diuretics as prescribed and monitor response
Implement fluid restriction as ordered (typically 1.5-2L/day)
Weigh patient daily at same time, on same scale, with similar clothing
Monitor electrolytes, especially potassium and sodium
Educate on low-sodium diet (2-3g/day)
rationales: Diuretics reduce fluid overload and pulmonary congestion
Fluid restriction prevents additional fluid accumulation
Daily weights provide objective measurement of fluid status
Diuretic therapy can cause electrolyte imbalances
Sodium restriction reduces fluid retention
interventions.frequency: Daily and PRN
specialConsiderations: Monitor for signs of dehydration with aggressive diuresis
Adjust diuretic timing to avoid nighttime diuresis and sleep disruption

expectedOutcomes: Vital signs within patient's normal range
Improved activity tolerance
Decreased fatigue
Improved ejection fraction on echocardiogram
Weight stabilized within 2 kg of baseline
Resolution of peripheral edema
Clear lung sounds
Balanced intake and output

title: COPD Exacerbation Management
description: Care plan for managing acute exacerbations of Chronic Obstructive Pulmonary Disease (COPD), focusing on improving ventilation, preventing complications, and promoting self-management.

assessments.title: Respiratory Assessment
points: Assess respiratory rate, depth, and pattern q2-4h and PRN
Auscultate lung sounds q4h and PRN
Monitor for use of accessory muscles, pursed-lip breathing
Assess for cyanosis of lips, nail beds, and skin
Evaluate sputum characteristics (color, amount, consistency)
assessments.description: Comprehensive respiratory assessment to evaluate COPD status and response to treatment

assessments.title: Oxygenation Status
points: Monitor oxygen saturation continuously or q2h
Assess arterial blood gas results as available
Evaluate response to oxygen therapy
Monitor for signs of carbon dioxide retention (drowsiness, confusion, headache)
assessments.description: Oxygen monitoring is critical in COPD exacerbation to prevent hypoxemia while avoiding CO2 narcosis

assessments.title: Activity Tolerance
points: Assess dyspnea using standardized scale (e.g., Modified Borg or Dyspnea Visual Analog Scale)
Evaluate activity tolerance and functional capacity
Assess for fatigue and energy conservation needs
assessments.description: Activity assessment helps determine functional limitations and guide rehabilitation

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Ineffective Breathing Pattern related to airflow obstruction as evidenced by dyspnea, abnormal respiratory rate, and use of accessory muscles
Impaired Gas Exchange related to ventilation-perfusion mismatch as evidenced by hypoxemia and dyspnea

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate improved breathing pattern as evidenced by normal respiratory rate, decreased use of accessory muscles, and reduced dyspnea
indicators: Respiratory rate 12-20/min
Minimal use of accessory muscles
Decreased dyspnea score
Effective cough with expectoration of secretions

goals.statement: Patient will maintain adequate oxygenation as evidenced by oxygen saturation within target range
indicators: Oxygen saturation 88-92% (or as prescribed)
Arterial blood gases within acceptable parameters
Alert and oriented mental status
Pink mucous membranes

interventions.title: Airway Management
actions: Administer bronchodilators as prescribed (short-acting beta-agonists, anticholinergics)
Administer corticosteroids as prescribed
Perform chest physiotherapy and postural drainage if indicated
Assist with effective coughing techniques
Encourage adequate hydration (2-3L/day unless contraindicated)
rationales: Bronchodilators relieve bronchoconstriction and improve airflow
Corticosteroids reduce airway inflammation
Chest physiotherapy mobilizes secretions
Effective coughing clears airways of secretions
Hydration thins secretions for easier expectoration
interventions.frequency: Every 2-6 hours as prescribed
specialConsiderations: Monitor for tachycardia and tremors with beta-agonists
Consider spacer device with MDIs for better medication delivery

interventions.title: Oxygen Therapy
actions: Administer oxygen at prescribed flow rate (typically 1-2 L/min)
Use appropriate delivery device (nasal cannula, Venturi mask)
Monitor oxygen saturation continuously
Adjust oxygen to maintain saturation 88-92% (or as prescribed)
Elevate head of bed 30-45 degrees
rationales: Low-flow oxygen corrects hypoxemia while minimizing CO2 retention risk
Appropriate delivery devices provide controlled oxygen concentration
Continuous monitoring ensures adequate oxygenation
Target saturation prevents hypoxemia while avoiding respiratory depression
Elevated position optimizes ventilation and reduces work of breathing
interventions.frequency: Continuous
specialConsiderations: Avoid high-flow oxygen which may suppress respiratory drive in CO2 retainers
Monitor for signs of CO2 narcosis with oxygen therapy

expectedOutcomes: Respiratory rate within normal range
Decreased use of accessory muscles
Reduced dyspnea score
Effective airway clearance
Oxygen saturation within target range (88-92% or as prescribed)
Improved arterial blood gas values
Alert and oriented mental status
Decreased dyspnea

title: Diabetic Ketoacidosis Management
description: Care plan for managing Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA), focusing on fluid resuscitation, insulin therapy, electrolyte management, and identification of precipitating factors.

assessments.title: Metabolic Assessment
points: Monitor blood glucose q1-2h until stable, then q4h
Monitor urine or serum ketones q4-6h until negative
Assess for signs of dehydration (dry mucous membranes, poor skin turgor, tachycardia)
Monitor for Kussmaul respirations (deep, rapid breathing)
Assess for acetone breath (fruity odor)
assessments.description: Metabolic assessment is crucial for evaluating DKA severity and response to treatment

assessments.title: Fluid and Electrolyte Status
points: Monitor vital signs q1h initially, then q4h when stable
Maintain strict intake and output records
Monitor electrolytes (especially potassium, sodium, chloride, bicarbonate) q2-4h initially
Assess for signs of hypokalemia (muscle weakness, cardiac arrhythmias)
Monitor BUN and creatinine for renal function
assessments.description: Fluid and electrolyte monitoring is essential as rapid shifts occur during DKA treatment

assessments.title: Neurological Assessment
points: Assess level of consciousness q1-2h
Monitor for signs of cerebral edema (headache, altered mental status, seizures)
Evaluate orientation and cognition
Assess pupillary responses and motor function
assessments.description: Neurological assessment helps detect complications like cerebral edema, particularly in pediatric patients

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Deficient Fluid Volume related to osmotic diuresis as evidenced by polyuria, dehydration, and hypotension
Risk for Electrolyte Imbalance related to fluid shifts and insulin therapy
relatedFactors: Insulin therapy causing intracellular potassium shift

goals.statement: Patient will achieve normal fluid volume status as evidenced by stable vital signs and improved hydration
indicators: Heart rate <100 bpm
Blood pressure within patient's normal range
Moist mucous membranes
Good skin turgor
Balanced intake and output

goals.statement: Patient will maintain normal blood glucose levels and negative ketones
indicators: Blood glucose 140-180 mg/dL
Negative serum or urine ketones
Normal anion gap
Serum bicarbonate >18 mEq/L

interventions.title: Fluid Resuscitation
actions: Administer isotonic fluid (0.9% NaCl) as prescribed (typically 15-20 mL/kg in first hour)
Continue IV fluid therapy as prescribed, typically 250-500 mL/hr
Monitor vital signs q15-30min during rapid fluid replacement
Assess for signs of fluid overload (crackles, edema, increased work of breathing)
Switch to 0.45% NaCl when serum glucose reaches 200-250 mg/dL
rationales: Rapid fluid replacement corrects dehydration and improves tissue perfusion
Continued fluid therapy replaces ongoing losses and corrects deficit
Frequent monitoring prevents complications from rapid fluid shifts
Fluid overload can lead to pulmonary edema, especially in patients with cardiac or renal disease
Hypotonic fluids prevent rapid drop in serum osmolality as glucose decreases
interventions.frequency: Continuous until rehydration achieved
specialConsiderations: Use caution in patients with heart failure or renal failure
Pediatric patients require more careful fluid management to prevent cerebral edema

interventions.title: Insulin Therapy
actions: Administer IV insulin as prescribed (typically 0.1 units/kg/hr)
Monitor blood glucose q1h until stable, then q2-4h
Adjust insulin rate based on glucose response and protocol
When glucose reaches 200-250 mg/dL, add dextrose to IV fluids
Transition to subcutaneous insulin when DKA resolved and patient eating
rationales: IV insulin reduces blood glucose and suppresses ketogenesis
Frequent monitoring allows timely insulin adjustments
Insulin rate adjustments maintain steady glucose decline (~50-75 mg/dL/hr)
Dextrose prevents hypoglycemia while continuing insulin to clear ketones
Transition to subcutaneous insulin prevents DKA recurrence
interventions.frequency: Continuous until DKA resolved
specialConsiderations: Continue insulin even when glucose normalizes if ketones still present
Overlap IV and subcutaneous insulin by 1-2 hours during transition

interventions.title: Electrolyte Management
actions: Monitor serum potassium q2-4h initially
Administer potassium replacement as prescribed when K+ <5.0 mEq/L
Monitor for signs of hypokalemia (muscle weakness, ECG changes)
Administer other electrolytes (phosphate, magnesium) as prescribed
Monitor acid-base status with arterial blood gases
rationales: Total body potassium is depleted in DKA despite possible initial hyperkalemia
Insulin therapy causes intracellular potassium shift, risking hypokalemia
Hypokalemia can cause cardiac arrhythmias and respiratory muscle weakness
Phosphate and magnesium are often depleted in DKA
Monitoring acid-base status tracks resolution of metabolic acidosis
interventions.frequency: Every 2-4 hours until stable
specialConsiderations: Do not give potassium if patient is anuric or has hyperkalemia
Bicarbonate therapy is rarely indicated except in severe acidosis (pH <6.9)

expectedOutcomes: Vital signs within normal range
Moist mucous membranes
Normal skin turgor
Balanced intake and output
Normal BUN and creatinine
Blood glucose 140-180 mg/dL
Negative ketones
Serum bicarbonate >18 mEq/L
Normal anion gap
Normal mental status

title: Acute Stroke Management
description: Care plan for the acute management of ischemic stroke, focusing on neurological assessment, thrombolytic therapy considerations, prevention of complications, and early rehabilitation.

assessments.title: Neurological Assessment
points: Perform NIH Stroke Scale assessment on admission and q4h
Monitor level of consciousness using Glasgow Coma Scale
Assess pupillary responses, motor strength, and sensory function
Evaluate speech and language function
Monitor for signs of increased intracranial pressure (headache, vomiting, decreased LOC)
assessments.description: Comprehensive neurological assessment is essential for monitoring stroke progression and response to treatment

assessments.title: Vital Signs and Hemodynamics
points: Monitor blood pressure q15min for 2 hours, then q30min for 6 hours, then q1h
Assess heart rate and rhythm continuously for arrhythmias
Monitor temperature q4h and treat fever >37.5°C promptly
Monitor oxygen saturation continuously
Assess respiratory pattern and effort
assessments.description: Hemodynamic monitoring is critical as blood pressure management differs based on treatment status and stroke type

assessments.title: Swallowing and Nutrition
points: Perform formal swallowing assessment before any oral intake
Maintain NPO status until swallowing assessment completed
Assess for signs of aspiration with oral intake
Monitor nutritional status and hydration
assessments.description: Dysphagia is common after stroke and increases risk of aspiration pneumonia

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Ineffective Cerebral Tissue Perfusion related to interruption of blood flow as evidenced by neurological deficits
Impaired Physical Mobility related to neuromuscular impairment as evidenced by limited range of motion and inability to purposefully move
definingCharacteristics: Limited ability to perform gross motor skills

goals.statement: Patient will maintain adequate cerebral perfusion as evidenced by stable or improved neurological status
indicators: Stable or improved NIH Stroke Scale score
Blood pressure within target range
Alert and responsive mental status
No signs of neurological deterioration

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate no complications of immobility
indicators: Intact skin integrity
No evidence of deep vein thrombosis
Clear lung sounds
Normal range of joint motion

interventions.title: Neurological Monitoring and Management
actions: Perform neurological assessments using standardized tools (NIHSS, GCS) q1-4h
Maintain head of bed at 30 degrees unless contraindicated
Implement blood pressure management per protocol (target depends on tPA administration)
Monitor for and report neurological deterioration immediately
Administer medications as prescribed (antihypertensives, anticonvulsants if needed)
rationales: Regular assessments detect changes in neurological status requiring intervention
Elevated head position optimizes cerebral perfusion and reduces ICP
Proper BP management prevents hemorrhagic transformation and maintains cerebral perfusion
Early detection of deterioration allows prompt intervention
Medications manage complications and prevent secondary injury
interventions.frequency: Every 1-4 hours based on acuity
specialConsiderations: For patients receiving tPA, monitor BP q15min for 2 hours, then q30min for 6 hours
Report BP >180/105 mmHg in patients who received tPA

interventions.title: Thrombolytic Therapy Management
actions: Administer tPA as prescribed if patient meets criteria
Monitor for bleeding (gums, IV sites, urine, stool)
Avoid invasive procedures for 24 hours post-tPA
Hold anticoagulants and antiplatelets for 24 hours post-tPA
Monitor for angioedema (facial swelling, tongue swelling, stridor)
rationales: tPA dissolves clots and can improve neurological outcomes if given within time window
Bleeding is the main complication of thrombolytic therapy
Invasive procedures increase bleeding risk after tPA
Anticoagulants increase bleeding risk after tPA
Angioedema is a potentially life-threatening complication of tPA
interventions.frequency: Continuous monitoring for first 24 hours post-tPA
specialConsiderations: Have emergency equipment readily available
Prepare to administer cryoprecipitate, fresh frozen plasma, or platelets if severe bleeding occurs

interventions.title: Dysphagia Management and Nutrition
actions: Maintain NPO status until formal swallowing assessment completed
Position patient upright at 90 degrees for meals if swallowing approved
Implement dysphagia diet recommendations from speech therapy
Monitor for signs of aspiration (coughing, choking, wet voice quality)
Provide alternative nutrition (NG or PEG tube) if indicated
rationales: Preventing oral intake until swallowing assessment reduces aspiration risk
Upright positioning reduces aspiration risk during meals
Modified diet textures improve swallowing safety
Early detection of aspiration prevents pneumonia
Alternative nutrition prevents malnutrition in patients with severe dysphagia
interventions.frequency: With all meals and oral medications
specialConsiderations: Ensure oral care before and after meals
Consider thickened liquids if recommended by speech therapy

evaluations.statement: Has neurological status remained stable or improved?
expectedOutcomes: Stable or improved NIHSS score
No new neurological deficits
Blood pressure within target range
No signs of increased intracranial pressure
evaluationMethods: Imaging studies (repeat CT or MRI if indicated)

evaluations.statement: Has patient remained free from complications?
expectedOutcomes: No evidence of hemorrhagic transformation
No signs of aspiration pneumonia
No pressure injuries
No deep vein thrombosis

title: Postoperative Care - Abdominal Surgery
description: Care plan for patients recovering from abdominal surgery, focusing on pain management, wound care, prevention of complications, and early mobilization to promote recovery.

assessments.title: Pain Assessment
points: Assess pain using numeric rating scale (0-10) q2-4h and PRN
Evaluate pain characteristics (location, quality, radiation, aggravating/relieving factors)
Assess effectiveness of pain interventions
Monitor for nonverbal signs of pain
Assess for patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) use if applicable
assessments.description: Comprehensive pain assessment is essential for effective postoperative pain management

assessments.title: Respiratory Assessment
points: Assess respiratory rate, depth, and pattern q4h
Auscultate lung sounds q8h
Monitor oxygen saturation q4h and PRN
Assess effectiveness of coughing and deep breathing
Monitor for signs of atelectasis or pneumonia
assessments.description: Respiratory assessment helps detect complications like atelectasis and pneumonia early

assessments.title: Surgical Site Assessment
points: Inspect incision for redness, swelling, drainage, or dehiscence q8h
Assess wound dressing for integrity and drainage
Monitor temperature q4h for first 48 hours, then q8h
Assess for signs of surgical site infection
Monitor drains for patency and output (amount, color, consistency)
assessments.description: Regular wound assessment helps detect complications early and guides intervention

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Acute Pain related to surgical incision and tissue trauma as evidenced by verbal reports of pain and guarding behavior
definingCharacteristics: Changes in vital signs during acute pain

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Infection related to surgical incision and invasive procedures
relatedFactors: Proximity to gastrointestinal contents during surgery

goals.statement: Patient will report adequate pain control (pain level ≤3/10) with prescribed interventions
indicators: Pain level ≤3/10 on numeric rating scale
Able to participate in activities of daily living
Able to participate in physical therapy
Demonstrates use of non-pharmacological pain management techniques

goals.statement: Patient will demonstrate wound healing without signs of infection
indicators: Incision edges well-approximated
No excessive redness, swelling, or drainage
No purulent drainage
Temperature <38°C
White blood cell count within normal range

interventions.title: Pain Management
actions: Administer prescribed analgesics on schedule and PRN
Utilize multimodal pain management approach (opioids, NSAIDs, acetaminophen)
Assist with patient-controlled analgesia (PCA) if ordered
Teach non-pharmacological pain management techniques (repositioning, relaxation)
Assess effectiveness of interventions 30-60 minutes after administration
rationales: Scheduled analgesics maintain therapeutic blood levels for better pain control
Multimodal approach targets different pain pathways for better relief with fewer side effects
PCA allows patient to manage breakthrough pain promptly
Non-pharmacological techniques complement medication for better pain control
Evaluation determines need for adjustments to pain management plan
interventions.frequency: Every 2-4 hours and PRN
specialConsiderations: Monitor for respiratory depression with opioids
Assess for constipation with opioid use and implement preventive measures

interventions.title: Wound Care and Infection Prevention
actions: Maintain sterile technique during dressing changes
Change dressings as ordered or when soiled
Monitor wound drainage and document characteristics
Administer prophylactic antibiotics as prescribed
Teach patient proper incision care and signs of infection to report
rationales: Sterile technique reduces risk of wound contamination
Regular dressing changes allow wound assessment and maintain clean environment
Monitoring drainage helps detect complications early
Prophylactic antibiotics prevent surgical site infections
Patient education promotes self-care and early reporting of complications
interventions.frequency: Every 8-24 hours based on wound status and orders
specialConsiderations: Use wound classification (clean, clean-contaminated, contaminated) to guide care
Consider negative pressure wound therapy for high-risk wounds

interventions.title: Early Mobilization
actions: Assist with progressive ambulation starting postoperative day 1
Help patient sit in chair 3 times daily for at least 30 minutes
Teach and assist with incentive spirometry q2h while awake
Encourage deep breathing and coughing exercises q2h
Apply sequential compression devices when in bed
rationales: Early ambulation prevents complications of immobility and promotes GI function
Sitting improves lung expansion and reduces atelectasis risk
Incentive spirometry prevents atelectasis and pneumonia
Deep breathing exercises expand lungs and mobilize secretions
Sequential compression devices prevent deep vein thrombosis
interventions.frequency: Multiple times daily
specialConsiderations: Provide adequate pain control before mobilization
Support incision during coughing with pillow or splinting

expectedOutcomes: Pain level ≤3/10 on numeric rating scale
Able to perform deep breathing and coughing
Able to participate in ambulation
Minimal use of breakthrough pain medication

title: Sepsis Management
description: Care plan for managing patients with sepsis, focusing on early recognition, fluid resuscitation, antimicrobial therapy, hemodynamic support, and prevention of organ dysfunction.

assessments.title: Hemodynamic Assessment
points: Monitor vital signs q15-30min until stable, then q1h
Assess for hypotension (SBP <90 mmHg or MAP <65 mmHg)
Monitor for tachycardia, tachypnea, and fever/hypothermia
Assess skin temperature, color, and capillary refill
Monitor urine output hourly (goal >0.5 mL/kg/hr)
assessments.description: Hemodynamic assessment is critical for early detection of septic shock and response to interventions

assessments.title: Infection Assessment
points: Assess for source of infection (respiratory, urinary, abdominal, skin, device-related)
Monitor temperature q2-4h
Obtain cultures as ordered before antibiotic administration
Monitor white blood cell count and differential
Assess for local signs of infection (erythema, purulence, tenderness)
assessments.description: Identifying the source of infection guides targeted antibiotic therapy and source control

assessments.title: Organ Function Assessment
points: Monitor mental status q1-2h
Assess respiratory status (rate, effort, oxygen saturation)
Monitor renal function (urine output, BUN, creatinine)
Assess liver function (bilirubin, transaminases)
Monitor coagulation status (platelets, INR, PTT, D-dimer)
assessments.description: Monitoring organ function helps detect and prevent multiple organ dysfunction syndrome

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Decreased Cardiac Output related to altered preload, afterload, and contractility as evidenced by hypotension and tachycardia
Risk for Ineffective Tissue Perfusion related to decreased cardiac output and microcirculatory dysfunction

goals.statement: Patient will achieve hemodynamic stability as evidenced by normal vital signs and adequate tissue perfusion
indicators: Mean arterial pressure ≥65 mmHg
Heart rate <100 bpm
Urine output >0.5 mL/kg/hr
Normal mental status
Lactate <2 mmol/L

goals.statement: Patient will show resolution of infection as evidenced by normalization of inflammatory markers and clinical improvement
indicators: Temperature 36-38°C
Normalization of white blood cell count
Resolution of signs and symptoms of infection
Negative follow-up cultures

interventions.title: Fluid Resuscitation
actions: Administer crystalloid fluids (30 mL/kg) within first 3 hours for hypotension or lactate ≥4 mmol/L
Use large-bore IV access (preferably two sites)
Monitor vital signs q15min during initial resuscitation
Assess for signs of fluid overload (crackles, edema, JVD)
Implement dynamic measures of fluid responsiveness when available (passive leg raise, stroke volume variation)
rationales: Early aggressive fluid resuscitation restores intravascular volume and tissue perfusion
Large-bore access allows rapid fluid administration
Frequent monitoring assesses response to fluid therapy
Fluid overload can worsen respiratory function and outcomes
Dynamic measures help determine ongoing fluid needs more accurately than static measures
interventions.frequency: First 3-6 hours, then as needed based on assessment
specialConsiderations: Use caution in patients with heart failure or renal failure
Consider albumin for patients requiring substantial crystalloids

interventions.title: Antimicrobial Therapy
actions: Obtain appropriate cultures before antibiotic administration when possible
Administer broad-spectrum antibiotics within 1 hour of sepsis recognition
Ensure appropriate dosing and timing of antibiotics
Assist with source control measures (drainage, debridement, device removal) as indicated
Monitor for antibiotic-related adverse effects
rationales: Cultures guide targeted therapy but should not delay antibiotic administration
Early appropriate antibiotics improve survival
Appropriate dosing ensures therapeutic levels
Source control is essential for infection resolution
Antibiotics can cause adverse effects requiring monitoring
interventions.frequency: According to prescribed schedule
specialConsiderations: Antibiotics should be narrowed based on culture results
Consider drug levels for antibiotics requiring therapeutic monitoring

interventions.title: Vasopressor Support
actions: Administer vasopressors if hypotension persists despite adequate fluid resuscitation
Use norepinephrine as first-line vasopressor (target MAP ≥65 mmHg)
Monitor for extravasation at peripheral IV sites if vasopressors administered peripherally
Obtain central venous access for prolonged vasopressor therapy
Titrate vasopressors based on MAP and signs of tissue perfusion
rationales: Vasopressors increase vascular tone and blood pressure when fluids alone are insufficient
Norepinephrine has favorable effects on both cardiac output and vascular tone
Extravasation can cause tissue necrosis
Central access is preferred for vasopressor administration
Titration balances adequate perfusion with excessive vasoconstriction
interventions.frequency: Continuous infusion with frequent assessment
specialConsiderations: Consider adding vasopressin or epinephrine for refractory shock
Use inotropes (dobutamine) if evidence of cardiac dysfunction

expectedOutcomes: MAP ≥65 mmHg without or with minimal vasopressor support
Heart rate <100 bpm
Urine output >0.5 mL/kg/hr
Lactate normalized or trending down
Warm extremities with capillary refill <3 seconds
Normalization of temperature
Decreasing white blood cell count and inflammatory markers
Resolution of signs and symptoms at infection site
Negative follow-up cultures if obtained

title: Postpartum Care
description: Care plan for postpartum patients, focusing on physiological recovery, breastfeeding support, emotional well-being, and education for self-care and newborn care.

assessments.title: Physical Recovery Assessment

Monitor fundal height, firmness, and position q4h for 24 hours, then q8h
Assess lochia (amount, color, odor, presence of clots) q4h
Evaluate perineal healing or cesarean incision q8h
Assess for bladder distention and urinary output
assessments.description: Physical assessment monitors recovery and detects complications like hemorrhage or infection

assessments.title: Lactation Assessment
points: Assess breasts for engorgement, tenderness, or signs of mastitis
Evaluate nipples for trauma, fissures, or pain
Assess infant latch, positioning, and feeding behaviors
Monitor infant feeding frequency, duration, and satiety cues
Assess maternal comfort and confidence with breastfeeding

assessments.title: Psychosocial Assessment
points: Assess maternal-infant bonding and attachment behaviors
Evaluate mood, affect, and emotional adjustment
Screen for postpartum depression using validated tool
Assess social support system and resources
Evaluate knowledge of self-care and infant care

Offloading devices prevent direct pressure on vulnerable areas

Barrier products protect skin from moisture-associated skin damage
Prompt incontinence management reduces moisture exposure
Massage over reddened areas can cause further tissue damage
interventions.frequency: Daily and PRN with hygiene and incontinence care
specialConsiderations: Use breathable underpads to manage moisture
Assess for and manage fungal infections in moist skin folds

interventions.title: Nutritional Support
actions: Ensure adequate intake of protein, calories, vitamins, and minerals
Collaborate with dietitian for nutritional assessment and plan
Offer nutritional supplements if oral intake is insufficient
Monitor hydration status and encourage adequate fluid intake
Monitor weight and laboratory values (albumin, prealbumin)
rationales: Adequate nutrition is essential for tissue repair and maintenance
Dietitian can provide specialized nutritional guidance
Supplements can help meet increased nutritional demands for healing
Hydration is important for skin turgor and overall health
Monitoring helps assess nutritional status and effectiveness of interventions

specialConsiderations: Consider specific nutrient needs for wound healing (e.g., vitamin C, zinc)
Address factors affecting oral intake (e.g., dysphagia, poor appetite)

Protecting periwound skin prevents further breakdown

specialConsiderations: Dressing choice depends on wound characteristics (stage, exudate, depth)

title: Hip Fracture - Postoperative Care
description: Care plan for patients recovering from hip fracture surgery (e.g., ORIF, hemiarthroplasty), focusing on pain control, early mobilization, prevention of complications (infection, DVT, pressure injury), and restoration of function.

assessments.title: Pain Assessment
points: Assess pain level using standardized scale (e.g., Numeric Rating Scale, Faces Pain Scale for cognitive impairment) q2-4h and PRN
Evaluate pain characteristics (location, quality, aggravating/relieving factors)
Assess effectiveness of analgesia, including non-pharmacological methods
Monitor for nonverbal signs of pain (grimacing, guarding, restlessness)
assessments.description: Effective pain management is crucial for comfort and enabling early mobilization.

assessments.title: Surgical Site and Neurovascular Assessment
points: Inspect surgical incision for redness, swelling, warmth, drainage, or signs of dehiscence q4-8h
Assess dressing for integrity and drainage amount/type
Perform neurovascular checks on affected extremity q2-4h (color, temperature, capillary refill, pulses, sensation, motor function)
Monitor for signs of compartment syndrome (severe pain, pallor, paresthesia, pulselessness, paralysis)
assessments.description: Monitors for wound healing, infection, and neurovascular compromise in the affected limb.

assessments.title: Mobility and Complication Risk Assessment
points: Assess ability to move in bed, transfer, and ambulate (based on weight-bearing status)
Evaluate for signs of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) (calf pain, swelling, redness, warmth) and pulmonary embolism (PE) (dyspnea, chest pain, tachycardia)
Assess respiratory status (lung sounds, SpO2) for atelectasis or pneumonia
Inspect skin for pressure injury risk, especially sacrum and heels
Monitor for delirium, especially in older adults
assessments.description: Focuses on early mobilization and prevention of common postoperative complications.

interventions.title: Pain Management
actions: Administer prescribed analgesics (opioids, NSAIDs, acetaminophen, nerve blocks) on schedule and PRN
Utilize multimodal analgesia approach to minimize opioid use and side effects
Teach and encourage use of non-pharmacological pain relief methods (ice, repositioning, distraction, relaxation)
Assess and document pain and effectiveness of interventions regularly
Pre-medicate before potentially painful activities (e.g., physical therapy)
rationales: Consistent analgesia maintains therapeutic levels for better pain control
Multimodal approach targets pain via different mechanisms, improving efficacy and reducing side effects
Non-pharmacological methods complement analgesics and empower patient
Regular assessment guides adjustments to pain plan
Pre-medication facilitates participation in rehabilitation

specialConsiderations: Monitor for opioid side effects (respiratory depression, constipation, sedation)

interventions.title: Early Mobilization and Rehabilitation
actions: Collaborate with physical therapist (PT) to initiate mobilization as early as post-op day 0 or 1

Reinforce prescribed exercises (e.g., ankle pumps, quad sets, gluteal sets, range of motion)
Ensure adherence to hip precautions if applicable (e.g., no adduction, no flexion >90 degrees, no internal rotation for posterior approach arthroplasty)
Encourage out-of-bed activities (sitting in chair for meals)
rationales: Early mobilization prevents complications of immobility and promotes functional recovery
PT provides expert guidance on safe progression of mobility
Exercises maintain muscle strength and joint mobility
Hip precautions prevent dislocation after arthroplasty
Reducing bed rest improves respiratory function and overall well-being

specialConsiderations: Ensure adequate pain control before mobilization

interventions.title: Prevention of Complications
actions: Wound Care: Maintain clean and dry dressing; monitor incision for signs of infection; perform dressing changes using aseptic technique as ordered.
DVT Prophylaxis: Administer anticoagulant medications as prescribed; apply mechanical prophylaxis (SCDs, compression stockings); encourage ankle pump exercises.
Respiratory Care: Encourage deep breathing and coughing exercises, use of incentive spirometer q1-2h while awake; promote early ambulation.
Pressure Injury Prevention: Reposition frequently (q2h in bed); use pressure-relieving devices on bed and chair; keep skin clean and dry; ensure adequate nutrition and hydration.
Neurovascular Monitoring: Perform regular checks of affected extremity; elevate leg to reduce edema as appropriate.
rationales: Aseptic technique prevents surgical site infection.
Anticoagulants and mechanical prophylaxis reduce DVT risk.
Respiratory exercises prevent atelectasis and pneumonia.
Pressure relief and skin care prevent pressure injuries.
Monitoring detects neurovascular compromise early.
interventions.frequency: Ongoing, with specific interventions at scheduled intervals
specialConsiderations: Monitor for bleeding with anticoagulants
Tailor pressure injury prevention to individual risk (Braden Scale)

interventions.title: Psychosocial Support and Education
actions: Provide emotional support and address anxiety related to surgery, pain, and recovery
Educate patient and family on hip precautions (if any), weight-bearing status, activity limitations, and home safety modifications
Discuss signs of complications to report after discharge
Involve family in care and discharge planning
Facilitate communication with multidisciplinary team (PT, OT, social work)
rationales: Emotional support reduces anxiety and promotes coping
Education empowers patient and family for self-care and safe recovery
Knowledge of warning signs enables prompt action if complications arise
Family involvement enhances support system
Coordinated care improves outcomes
interventions.frequency: Ongoing throughout hospitalization
specialConsiderations: Screen for delirium and manage appropriately if present
Address concerns about body image or long-term disability

expectedOutcomes: Patient reports pain at an acceptable level (e.g., ≤3-4/10)
Able to participate in PT and ADLs without excessive pain
Reduced reliance on opioid analgesics over time

evaluations.statement: Is patient progressing with mobility and function?
expectedOutcomes: Achieves mobility goals set with PT (e.g., ambulation distance, transfers)
Demonstrates correct use of assistive devices and adherence to precautions
Increased independence in ADLs
evaluationMethods: Observation of mobility and ADL performance

evaluations.statement: Are complications being prevented or managed effectively?
expectedOutcomes: Surgical wound healing without signs of infection
No clinical evidence of DVT/PE
Lungs clear, afebrile
Skin intact, no new pressure injuries
Neurovascular status of affected limb stable

references.author: American Academy of Orthopaedic Surgeons (AAOS)
references.title: Management of Hip Fractures in the Elderly: Evidence-Based Clinical Practice Guideline

references.title: Management of Hip Fractures in the Elderly.

timeFrame: Acute care 3-7 days, rehabilitation weeks to months

title: Pediatric Fever Management
description: Care plan for managing fever in pediatric patients, focusing on comfort measures, appropriate use of antipyretics, hydration, identification of serious underlying illness, and parental education.

assessments.title: Fever and Symptom Assessment
points: Measure temperature using appropriate method for age (rectal for <3 months, axillary, oral, tympanic, temporal for older)
Assess onset, duration, and pattern of fever
Evaluate associated symptoms (rash, cough, vomiting, diarrhea, lethargy, irritability, poor feeding)
Observe child's activity level, hydration status, and overall appearance (toxic vs. non-toxic)
Assess for signs of serious illness (meningismus, respiratory distress, petechiae, inconsolable crying)
assessments.description: Differentiates simple febrile illness from potentially serious conditions requiring urgent attention.

assessments.title: Hydration and Comfort Assessment
points: Assess hydration status (mucous membranes, skin turgor, fontanelle in infants, urine output/wet diapers)
Evaluate child's comfort level (fussiness, crying, ability to be consoled)
Assess for pain or discomfort related to underlying illness
Observe sleep patterns and appetite
assessments.description: Fever increases fluid loss and can cause discomfort; maintaining hydration and comfort is key.

assessments.title: Parental Knowledge and Anxiety Assessment
points: Assess parental understanding of fever and its management
Evaluate parental anxiety level regarding the child's illness ('fever phobia')
Assess current fever management practices at home (medications used, dosing, non-pharmacological methods)
Identify parental concerns and questions
assessments.description: Addresses parental understanding and anxiety, which are important for effective home management.

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Hyperthermia related to infectious process or inflammatory response as evidenced by elevated body temperature
definingCharacteristics: Body temperature above normal range for age and measurement method
Flushed skin, skin warm to touch

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Deficient Fluid Volume related to increased metabolic rate, diaphoresis, and potential decreased oral intake
relatedFactors: Decreased oral intake due to malaise or sore throat
definingCharacteristics: Potential for decreased fluid intake or increased losses

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Deficient Knowledge (Parental) regarding appropriate fever management as evidenced by incorrect antipyretic dosing or excessive anxiety
relatedFactors: Lack of information or misinformation about fever
definingCharacteristics: Incorrect administration of antipyretics (dose, frequency, alternating)
Overuse or underuse of comfort measures
Expresses significant anxiety or fear about fever ('fever phobia')

goals.statement: Child will maintain a body temperature that promotes comfort and physiological stability
indicators: Temperature reduction to a level where child is more comfortable (not necessarily afebrile)
Improved activity level and responsiveness
Decreased irritability or fussiness
Parents verbalize understanding that goal is comfort, not eliminating fever entirely

goals.statement: Child will maintain adequate hydration status
indicators: Moist mucous membranes
Good skin turgor
Adequate urine output (e.g., 1-2 mL/kg/hr or appropriate number of wet diapers for age)
Soft, flat fontanelle (infants)
Active and alert (age-appropriate)

goals.statement: Parents will demonstrate understanding of appropriate fever management and when to seek further medical attention
indicators: Verbalize correct antipyretic (acetaminophen, ibuprofen) dosing and frequency for child's age/weight
Describe appropriate non-pharmacological comfort measures
Identify warning signs requiring prompt medical evaluation
Express reduced anxiety regarding fever management
goals.timeframe: By end of education session or discharge

interventions.title: Fever Reduction and Comfort Measures
actions: Administer antipyretics (acetaminophen or ibuprofen) as prescribed, based on child's weight and age. Do NOT alternate routinely.
Educate parents on correct dosing, timing, and not exceeding maximum daily doses.
Offer light clothing and bedding; avoid overdressing or bundling.
Encourage rest in a comfortable, cool environment.
Consider lukewarm (tepid) sponge baths only if child is very uncomfortable and temperature is very high; avoid cold water or alcohol baths.
rationales: Antipyretics reduce fever by inhibiting prostaglandin synthesis, improving comfort.
Correct dosing prevents toxicity; routine alternating is not generally recommended due to dosing error risk.
Light clothing allows heat dissipation.
Rest conserves energy; cool environment aids heat loss.
Tepid sponging can provide temporary relief but may cause shivering if water is too cold; alcohol is dangerous.
interventions.frequency: Antipyretics per order (e.g., q4-6h for acetaminophen, q6-8h for ibuprofen), comfort measures ongoing
specialConsiderations: Ibuprofen generally not recommended for infants <6 months.
Focus on child's comfort rather than solely on the number on the thermometer.
Aspirin should NOT be used in children due to risk of Reye's syndrome.

interventions.title: Hydration Promotion
actions: Encourage frequent small sips of clear fluids (water, oral rehydration solution, diluted juice, popsicles).
Continue breastfeeding or formula feeding for infants, possibly with increased frequency.
Monitor intake and output (number of wet diapers, urine characteristics).
Assess for signs of dehydration regularly.
If oral intake is poor, consult physician regarding need for IV fluids (in severe cases).
rationales: Fever increases fluid requirements; frequent small sips are often better tolerated.
Breast milk/formula provides fluids and nutrition.
Monitoring I&O helps assess hydration adequacy.
Early detection of dehydration allows for prompt intervention.
IV fluids may be needed if oral rehydration fails.
interventions.frequency: Ongoing encouragement of fluids, I&O monitoring q4-8h or per diaper change
specialConsiderations: Oral rehydration solutions are preferred if vomiting or diarrhea is present.
Avoid sugary drinks which can worsen diarrhea.

interventions.title: Parental Education and Support
actions: Educate parents that fever is a normal response to infection and not always harmful.
Teach how to accurately measure temperature.
Provide clear, written instructions on antipyretic dosing and administration.
Discuss warning signs that warrant immediate medical attention (e.g., lethargy, difficulty breathing, stiff neck, inconsolable crying, rash, signs of dehydration, seizure, fever in infant <3 months).
Address parental concerns and provide reassurance; correct misconceptions about 'fever phobia'.
rationales: Understanding fever's role can reduce parental anxiety.
Accurate measurement guides management.
Written instructions reduce dosing errors.
Knowing warning signs ensures timely care for serious illness.
Addressing anxiety and misinformation improves adherence and appropriate care.
interventions.frequency: Throughout interaction, with focused education session before discharge or end of visit
specialConsiderations: Use teach-back method to ensure understanding.
Provide resources for reliable information (e.g., AAP website).

evaluations.statement: Is the child more comfortable and temperature stabilized?
expectedOutcomes: Temperature reduced to a level associated with improved comfort (e.g., <38.5-39°C or 101-102°F).
Child appears less irritable, more active, or sleeping comfortably.
Parents report child seems more comfortable.
evaluationMethods: Observation of child's behavior and activity level.

expectedOutcomes: Child taking fluids well.
Good skin turgor, moist mucous membranes.
Adequate number of wet diapers or urine output.
No clinical signs of dehydration.
evaluationMethods: Parental report of fluid intake and wet diapers.

evaluations.statement: Do parents understand fever management and warning signs?
expectedOutcomes: Parents can verbalize correct antipyretic dosing and administration.
Parents can list key warning signs requiring medical attention.
Parents express increased confidence and reduced anxiety in managing fever at home.
evaluationMethods: Observation of parental interaction with child and medication administration if applicable.

references.author: American Academy of Pediatrics (AAP) Committee on Practice and Ambulatory Medicine, Section on Emergency Medicine, Committee on Hospital Care
references.title: Clinical Practice Guideline: Fever and Antipyretic Use in Children.

references.author: Sullivan JE, Farrar HC, Section on Clinical Pharmacology and Therapeutics, Committee on Drugs.
references.title: Fever and Antipyretic Use in Children.

notes: The primary goal of fever management in children is to improve comfort, not to normalize temperature. Always investigate the cause of fever, especially in young infants or if fever is prolonged or accompanied by concerning symptoms. Febrile seizures, while frightening, are generally benign in simple cases but warrant evaluation.
timeFrame: Typically 1-5 days for simple febrile illness

title: Palliative Care - Symptom Management
description: Care plan for patients receiving palliative care, focusing on comprehensive symptom management (pain, dyspnea, nausea, anxiety, etc.), enhancing quality of life, supporting patient and family goals, and facilitating communication.

assessments.title: Comprehensive Symptom Assessment
points: Assess for presence, intensity, and impact of multiple symptoms (pain, dyspnea, nausea/vomiting, constipation, fatigue, anxiety, depression, delirium) using validated scales (e.g., Edmonton Symptom Assessment System - ESAS, Numeric Rating Scale for pain).
Evaluate characteristics of each symptom (onset, location, quality, aggravating/relieving factors, timing).
Assess impact of symptoms on functional status, mood, and quality of life.
Review current medication regimen and its effectiveness/side effects.
assessments.description: Systematic assessment identifies distressing symptoms and guides individualized management.

assessments.title: Psychosocial, Spiritual, and Cultural Assessment
points: Assess patient's and family's understanding of illness, prognosis, and goals of care.
Evaluate coping mechanisms, emotional state (anxiety, depression, fear, hope), and sources of distress.
Explore spiritual beliefs, needs, and sources of comfort or conflict.
Assess cultural values and preferences related to illness, decision-making, and end-of-life care.
Identify family dynamics, support systems, and caregiver needs/stress.
assessments.description: Holistic assessment addresses the multifaceted needs of patients and families in palliative care.

assessments.title: Functional and Quality of Life Assessment
points: Assess ability to perform activities of daily living (ADLs) and instrumental ADLs (IADLs).
Evaluate overall quality of life from patient's perspective (e.g., using QOL scales).
Assess for sources of meaning, joy, and comfort.
Explore patient's wishes, values, and preferences for care, including advance care planning.
Assess for caregiver burden and need for respite or support.
assessments.description: Focuses on maintaining function and enhancing quality of life according to patient's priorities.

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Chronic Pain related to underlying disease process or treatment side effects as evidenced by self-report of pain and functional impairment
relatedFactors: Cancer, organ failure, neurological conditions, etc.
definingCharacteristics: Verbal report of persistent or recurrent pain (e.g., >4/10)

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Dyspnea related to disease progression or complications as evidenced by shortness of breath and increased work of breathing
definingCharacteristics: Subjective report of shortness of breath or difficulty breathing
Increased respiratory rate, use of accessory muscles
Anxiety or fear related to breathing difficulty

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Anticipatory Grieving related to impending loss (health, function, life) as evidenced by expression of sorrow, anger, or withdrawal
relatedFactors: Progressive decline in health and function
Loss of independence, roles, or future plans
definingCharacteristics: Expression of sadness, anger, guilt, or anxiety about future losses

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Caregiver Role Strain related to providing complex care and emotional support for a seriously ill loved one
relatedFactors: Severity of patient's illness and dependency
Emotional and physical demands of caregiving
definingCharacteristics: Caregiver reports feeling overwhelmed, stressed, or fatigued
Social isolation, neglect of personal needs
Anxiety, depression, or irritability in caregiver

goals.statement: Patient will experience optimal symptom control and comfort
indicators: Pain reported at an acceptable level (e.g., ≤3/10) or patient-defined comfort goal
Dyspnea managed effectively, allowing for rest and desired activities
Nausea, constipation, and other distressing symptoms minimized
Patient reports improved overall comfort
goals.timeframe: Ongoing, with regular reassessment and adjustment

goals.statement: Patient and family will demonstrate effective coping with illness and express feelings related to loss and grief
indicators: Patient and family verbalize understanding of illness trajectory and goals of care
Utilize available support systems (spiritual care, counseling, support groups)
Express feelings openly and constructively
Participate in advance care planning discussions

goals.statement: Patient's quality of life will be enhanced and maintained according to their values and preferences
indicators: Patient participates in activities that are meaningful to them
Reports satisfaction with care and decision-making
Maintains dignity and sense of self
Spiritual and cultural needs are addressed

interventions.title: Pain Management
actions: Administer analgesics (opioids, non-opioids, adjuvants) regularly and PRN based on comprehensive assessment and WHO analgesic ladder principles.
Titrate doses to achieve optimal pain relief with minimal side effects.
Educate patient and family on medication regimen, side effect management (especially constipation with opioids), and importance of reporting pain.
Explore and implement non-pharmacological pain relief measures (massage, heat/cold, relaxation, TENS, music therapy).
Consider interventional pain management techniques if indicated (nerve blocks, palliative radiation).
rationales: Systematic approach to analgesia ensures effective pain control.
Titration individualizes therapy.
Education empowers self-management and addresses fears about opioids.
Non-pharmacological methods complement analgesics and improve comfort.
Interventional techniques can manage refractory pain.
interventions.frequency: Analgesics per order (often scheduled with PRN), assessment ongoing
specialConsiderations: Proactively manage opioid-induced constipation.
Address fears of addiction; differentiate from tolerance and physical dependence.

interventions.title: Dyspnea Management
actions: Identify and treat reversible causes of dyspnea (e.g., infection, pleural effusion, anemia).
Administer opioids (e.g., low-dose morphine) as prescribed for symptomatic relief of dyspnea.
Provide supplemental oxygen if hypoxic and it improves comfort (not all dyspnea is hypoxia-related).
Teach energy conservation techniques and pursed-lip breathing.
Use fans to create airflow across face; maintain calm, cool environment; position for comfort (e.g., upright).
rationales: Treating underlying causes can alleviate dyspnea.
Opioids reduce the sensation of breathlessness.
Oxygen therapy is for hypoxia; comfort is the goal.
Techniques reduce work of breathing and anxiety.
Environmental and positioning strategies can ease dyspnea.
interventions.frequency: Ongoing assessment and interventions as needed
specialConsiderations: Anxiolytics (e.g., benzodiazepines) may be helpful if anxiety exacerbates dyspnea.
Educate that opioids for dyspnea are safe and effective at appropriate doses.

interventions.title: Management of Other Common Symptoms
actions: Nausea/Vomiting: Administer antiemetics based on cause; offer small, frequent meals; manage odors.
Constipation: Implement bowel regimen (stool softeners, laxatives); encourage fluids and mobility as able; assess for impaction.
Fatigue: Identify contributing factors; teach energy conservation; encourage short rest periods; explore meaning of fatigue.
Anxiety/Depression: Provide emotional support; teach coping strategies; administer anxiolytics/antidepressants as prescribed; refer for counseling.
Delirium: Identify and treat underlying causes; provide calm, familiar environment; reorient frequently; consider antipsychotics for agitation if distressing.
rationales: Targeted interventions based on symptom etiology are most effective.
Proactive management (e.g., bowel regimen) prevents worsening symptoms.
Multifaceted approach addresses physical and psychosocial aspects of fatigue.
Addressing psychological distress improves overall well-being.
Managing delirium focuses on safety and reorientation.
interventions.frequency: Ongoing assessment and proactive management
specialConsiderations: Symptom clusters are common; interventions may need to address multiple symptoms.
Non-pharmacological approaches should always be integrated.

interventions.title: Psychosocial, Spiritual, and Bereavement Support
actions: Facilitate open communication about fears, hopes, and end-of-life wishes (advance care planning).
Provide active listening, empathy, and emotional support to patient and family.
Offer spiritual care consults or support consistent with patient's beliefs.
Assist family in identifying coping strategies and accessing resources.
Provide information and support regarding grief and bereavement process, including referrals.
rationales: Open communication respects autonomy and facilitates goal-concordant care.
Emotional support validates feelings and reduces distress.
Spiritual care addresses existential concerns.
Supporting family coping reduces caregiver burden.
Bereavement support helps families navigate loss.
interventions.frequency: Ongoing throughout care, intensified as end of life approaches
specialConsiderations: Cultural sensitivity is paramount in all discussions.
Recognize signs of complicated grief in family members.

expectedOutcomes: Patient reports acceptable level of comfort for key symptoms (pain, dyspnea, nausea).
Observed signs of distress are minimized.
Patient is able to rest comfortably and participate in desired activities to extent possible.
evaluationMethods: Regular symptom assessment using validated scales (ESAS, pain scales).
Patient and family reports of comfort and symptom relief.
Observation of patient's behavior and functional status.

evaluations.statement: Are psychosocial and spiritual needs being met?
expectedOutcomes: Patient and family express feelings and concerns.
Report feeling supported and understood.
Spiritual needs addressed according to patient's wishes.
Advance care planning documented and respected.
evaluationMethods: Feedback from spiritual care or counseling services.
Review of advance directives and care plan discussions.

expectedOutcomes: Patient reports satisfaction with quality of life.
Engages in activities that provide meaning and comfort.
Maintains dignity and personal control to the extent possible.
Caregivers report feeling supported and able to manage.
evaluationMethods: Observation of patient engagement and mood.
Caregiver feedback and assessment of burden.
