references.title: WHO Definition of Palliative Care

references.author: National Consensus Project for Quality Palliative Care
references.title: Clinical Practice Guidelines for Quality Palliative Care, 4th edition
references.source: National Coalition for Hospice and Palliative Care

notes: Palliative care is an interdisciplinary approach. Effective communication and teamwork are essential. Goals of care may change over time; regular discussions with patient and family are crucial to ensure care remains aligned with their wishes.
timeFrame: Variable, depending on illness trajectory (can be months to years)

title: Burn Injury Management - Acute Phase
description: Care plan for the acute phase of major burn injury, focusing on airway management, fluid resuscitation, wound care, infection prevention, pain control, and thermoregulation.

assessments.title: Airway and Respiratory Assessment
points: Assess for signs of inhalation injury (facial burns, singed nasal hairs, soot in sputum, hoarseness, stridor, wheezing, dyspnea).
Monitor respiratory rate, effort, oxygen saturation (SpO2), and arterial blood gases (ABGs).
Auscultate lung sounds for adventitious sounds.
Assess for carbon monoxide poisoning if suspected (cherry-red skin, headache, confusion; check carboxyhemoglobin levels).
assessments.description: Early recognition and management of airway compromise or inhalation injury is critical.

assessments.title: Burn Wound and Circulatory Assessment
points: Estimate Total Body Surface Area (TBSA) burned using Rule of Nines or Lund-Browder chart.
Assess burn depth (superficial, partial-thickness, full-thickness).
Monitor vital signs frequently (HR, BP, MAP, temperature).
Assess peripheral pulses, capillary refill, and skin color/temperature, especially in circumferential burns.
Monitor urine output hourly (goal often 0.5-1 mL/kg/hr for adults, 1-2 mL/kg/hr for children).
assessments.description: Accurate burn assessment guides fluid resuscitation and wound care; circulatory monitoring detects hypovolemia or compartment syndrome.

assessments.title: Fluid, Electrolyte, and Metabolic Assessment
points: Monitor serum electrolytes (sodium, potassium, chloride, calcium), BUN, creatinine, and glucose.
Assess for signs of hypovolemic shock (tachycardia, hypotension, decreased urine output, altered mental status).
Monitor core body temperature for hypothermia or hyperthermia.
Assess nutritional needs (hypermetabolic state begins early).
assessments.description: Massive fluid shifts and metabolic changes occur post-burn, requiring intensive monitoring.

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Ineffective Airway Clearance / Impaired Gas Exchange related to inhalation injury, airway edema, or restrictive eschar on chest
relatedFactors: Thermal or chemical injury to airways
definingCharacteristics: Dyspnea, tachypnea, use of accessory muscles

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Deficient Fluid Volume related to plasma loss from burn wounds and capillary leakage as evidenced by tachycardia, hypotension, and decreased urine output
relatedFactors: Increased capillary permeability leading to third-spacing of fluid
Evaporative water loss from burn surface
definingCharacteristics: Decreased urine output (<0.5 mL/kg/hr in adults)
Poor skin turgor in unburned areas

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Acute Pain related to nerve exposure, tissue damage, and inflammatory mediators as evidenced by self-report of severe pain and physiological responses
relatedFactors: Destruction of skin layers and exposure of nerve endings

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Infection related to loss of skin barrier, impaired immune response, and invasive procedures
relatedFactors: Contamination from environment or endogenous flora

goals.statement: Patient will maintain a patent airway and adequate oxygenation/ventilation
indicators: Respiratory rate 12-20 breaths/min (age-appropriate)
SpO2 >92% (or as per baseline)
Clear breath sounds or improving
Absence of stridor or respiratory distress
ABGs within acceptable limits

goals.statement: Patient will achieve and maintain hemodynamic stability with adequate tissue perfusion
indicators: MAP ≥65 mmHg (or age-appropriate)
Heart rate within normal limits for age and condition
Urine output ≥0.5-1 mL/kg/hr (adults), 1-2 mL/kg/hr (children)
Alert mental status or baseline
Warm extremities with good capillary refill

goals.statement: Patient will report pain at a manageable level (e.g., ≤3-4/10) or demonstrate signs of comfort
indicators: Pain score consistently at or below target level
Able to participate in care and rest adequately
Minimal nonverbal signs of pain
Effective use of multimodal analgesia
goals.timeframe: Ongoing, with adjustments based on procedures

goals.statement: Patient will remain free from systemic infection and wound infection will be controlled
indicators: Temperature within normal range (or controlled if hypermetabolic)
WBC count trending towards normal
Negative blood cultures
Burn wounds show signs of healing without purulence or spreading cellulitis

interventions.title: Airway Management and Respiratory Support
actions: Administer humidified oxygen as prescribed; prepare for early intubation if signs of inhalation injury or airway compromise.
Elevate head of bed 30-45 degrees to reduce airway edema and improve ventilation.
Perform endotracheal suctioning as needed if intubated; provide meticulous oral care.
Monitor for signs of respiratory distress; report changes immediately.
For circumferential chest burns, prepare for or assist with escharotomy if ventilation is compromised.
rationales: Maintaining patent airway is paramount; inhalation injury can cause rapid edema.
HOB elevation aids breathing and reduces swelling.
Suctioning clears secretions; oral care prevents VAP.
Early detection of distress allows prompt intervention.
Escharotomy relieves restriction on chest expansion.
interventions.frequency: Continuous monitoring, interventions as needed
specialConsiderations: Assume inhalation injury in enclosed space fires until ruled out.
Monitor carboxyhemoglobin levels and administer 100% oxygen for CO poisoning.

interventions.title: Fluid Resuscitation
actions: Establish large-bore IV access (preferably two sites, through unburned skin if possible).

Administer warmed crystalloid solutions (e.g., Lactated Ringer's) using Parkland formula (or other institutional protocol) as a guide: typically 2-4 mL x kg x %TBSA, half in first 8 hrs, rest over next 16 hrs.
Titrate IV fluids based on urine output, MAP, HR, and mental status (formula is a guide, not absolute).
Monitor hourly urine output meticulously.
Assess for signs of fluid overload (pulmonary edema, peripheral edema in unburned areas).
rationales: Large-bore access needed for rapid fluid administration.
Aggressive fluid resuscitation replaces losses from capillary leak and prevents hypovolemic shock; warmed fluids prevent hypothermia.
Titration to physiological parameters is crucial for optimal resuscitation.
Urine output is a key indicator of renal perfusion and fluid status.
Over-resuscitation can lead to complications (compartment syndrome, ARDS).
interventions.frequency: Continuous IV infusion, hourly I&O and vital sign monitoring
specialConsiderations: Time of resuscitation starts from time of burn, not time of hospital arrival.
Electrical burns may require more fluid due to deep tissue injury.
Consider colloid administration after first 24 hours if indicated.

interventions.title: Burn Wound Care
actions: Cleanse wounds gently with prescribed solution (e.g., sterile water, saline, chlorhexidine).
Apply topical antimicrobial agents (e.g., silver sulfadiazine, mafenide acetate, bacitracin) as ordered.
Cover wounds with appropriate dressings (e.g., non-adherent, absorbent, silver-impregnated).
Maintain aseptic technique during all wound care.
Monitor for signs of infection (odor, purulence, increased pain, erythema extending beyond burn margin).
rationales: Cleansing removes debris and reduces bacterial load.
Topical antimicrobials prevent or treat wound infection.
Dressings protect wound, manage exudate, and promote healing.
Aseptic technique minimizes contamination.
Early detection of infection guides treatment.
interventions.frequency: Typically daily or twice daily, or as per specific dressing requirements
specialConsiderations: Debridement of loose eschar and blisters may be performed.
Pain management is crucial before and during wound care.
Specialized dressings (e.g., biological, synthetic) may be used.

interventions.title: Pain Management
actions: Administer IV opioid analgesics for severe pain, titrating to effect.
Provide background (long-acting) and breakthrough (short-acting) pain relief.
Consider anxiolytics to manage anxiety component of pain.
Use non-pharmacological methods (distraction, guided imagery, VR) as adjuncts.
Assess and treat procedural pain aggressively before wound care or debridement.
rationales: IV route is preferred initially due to impaired absorption from other routes.
Multimodal approach provides consistent pain control.
Anxiety can exacerbate pain perception.
Non-pharmacological methods can reduce opioid requirements.
Procedural pain is often intense and requires pre-emptive analgesia.
interventions.frequency: Scheduled and PRN analgesia, continuous assessment
specialConsiderations: Monitor for respiratory depression with opioids.
Patients may develop tolerance quickly, requiring dose escalation.
Non-verbal pain assessment tools for intubated/non-communicative patients.

interventions.title: Infection Control and Thermoregulation
actions: Implement strict hand hygiene and contact precautions.
Maintain a warm environment (room temperature 28-33°C or 82-91°F) and use warming blankets/devices to prevent hypothermia.
Monitor core body temperature regularly.
Administer tetanus prophylaxis as indicated.
Obtain wound cultures if infection suspected; systemic antibiotics based on culture results or signs of sepsis.
rationales: Prevents cross-contamination and nosocomial infections.
Burn patients lose ability to thermoregulate and are prone to hypothermia.
Detects hypothermia or fever promptly.
Burn wounds are tetanus-prone.
Guides appropriate antibiotic therapy.
interventions.frequency: Ongoing environmental control, temperature monitoring q1-4h
specialConsiderations: Reverse isolation may be used in some burn units.
Prophylactic systemic antibiotics are generally not recommended.

evaluations.statement: Is airway patent and ventilation/oxygenation adequate?
expectedOutcomes: No stridor or signs of respiratory distress.
SpO2 and ABGs within acceptable limits.
Clear or improving lung sounds.
Effective clearance of secretions if intubated.

evaluations.statement: Is fluid resuscitation adequate and hemodynamic stability achieved?
expectedOutcomes: Urine output within target range.
MAP and heart rate stable and within acceptable limits.
Alert mental status or return to baseline.
No signs of severe hypovolemia or fluid overload.
Patient reports pain at a manageable level.
Able to tolerate necessary procedures and rest.
Minimal non-verbal indicators of pain.
Side effects of analgesia managed.
No signs of systemic sepsis.
Wound cultures show decreasing bacterial load or no pathogenic growth.
Wounds appear clean and granulating (if appropriate for stage).
Temperature stable.

references.author: American Burn Association (ABA)
references.title: Practice Guidelines for Burn Care

references.author: Pham TN, Cancio LC, Gibran NS.
references.title: American Burn Association practice guidelines burn shock resuscitation.

notes: Burn care is highly specialized and requires an interdisciplinary team. Nutritional support (high protein, high calorie) is crucial from early phase. Psychosocial support for patient and family is vital due to traumatic nature of injury and long recovery.
timeFrame: Acute phase typically first 24-72 hours, but intensive care may last weeks.

title: Substance Use Disorder - Withdrawal Management
description: Care plan for managing acute withdrawal from substances (e.g., alcohol, opioids, benzodiazepines), focusing on safety, symptom relief, supportive care, and linkage to ongoing treatment.

assessments.title: Substance Use and Withdrawal Assessment
points: Identify substance(s) used, amount, frequency, route, and last use.
Use standardized withdrawal scales (e.g., CIWA-Ar for alcohol, COWS for opioids, CINA for benzodiazepines) regularly.
Assess for specific withdrawal symptoms (nausea, vomiting, tremors, anxiety, agitation, hallucinations, seizures, autonomic hyperactivity).
Monitor vital signs frequently (HR, BP, temperature, RR, SpO2).
Assess for history of complicated withdrawal (seizures, delirium tremens).
assessments.description: Accurate assessment guides appropriate pharmacological and supportive interventions for safe withdrawal.

assessments.title: Medical and Psychiatric Comorbidity Assessment
points: Screen for co-occurring medical conditions (liver disease, infections like HIV/HCV, malnutrition, trauma).
Assess for co-occurring psychiatric disorders (depression, anxiety, PTSD, psychosis).
Evaluate nutritional status and hydration.
Assess for pregnancy, if applicable, as withdrawal protocols may differ.
assessments.description: Identifies conditions that may complicate withdrawal or require concurrent treatment.

assessments.title: Safety and Psychosocial Assessment
points: Assess for suicidal or homicidal ideation, especially if psychiatric comorbidity or severe distress.
Evaluate level of motivation for change and treatment engagement.
Assess social support system, living situation, and potential relapse triggers.
Explore patient's understanding of addiction and withdrawal process.
Assess for risk of elopement or leaving against medical advice.
assessments.description: Ensures patient safety, identifies support needs, and informs discharge planning.

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Injury related to central nervous system agitation (e.g., seizures, delirium) or depression (e.g., overdose if relapse) during withdrawal
relatedFactors: Abrupt cessation of substance with physiological dependence
Neurochemical imbalances during withdrawal (e.g., GABA/glutamate dysregulation in alcohol/benzo withdrawal)
definingCharacteristics: Early signs of withdrawal (tremors, anxiety, agitation)

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Acute Confusion / Disturbed Sensory Perception related to substance withdrawal (e.g., delirium tremens, hallucinosis) as evidenced by disorientation, hallucinations, or agitation
definingCharacteristics: Disorientation to time, place, or person

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Ineffective Coping related to substance dependence and overwhelming withdrawal symptoms as evidenced by craving, anxiety, and inability to manage distress
relatedFactors: Physiological and psychological dependence on substance
High levels of stress and anxiety
definingCharacteristics: Verbalization of inability to cope with withdrawal symptoms

nursingDiagnoses.statement: Risk for Imbalanced Fluid Volume / Nutrition: Less Than Body Requirements related to nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, and decreased intake during withdrawal
relatedFactors: Gastrointestinal upset common in withdrawal (opioids, alcohol)
Anorexia or lack of interest in food/fluids
definingCharacteristics: Reports of nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea

goals.statement: Patient will complete withdrawal safely with minimal complications (e.g., no seizures, delirium managed)
indicators: Withdrawal symptoms managed effectively with medication (e.g., CIWA <8-10, COWS <5-12)
Vital signs remain within acceptable limits
No seizures, delirium, or other severe complications
Patient remains oriented or baseline mental status restored
goals.timeframe: Throughout acute withdrawal period (typically 3-10 days, substance-dependent)

goals.statement: Patient will experience improved comfort and reduced distress during withdrawal
indicators: Reports decreased severity of withdrawal symptoms (nausea, pain, anxiety)
Able to rest and sleep adequately
Reduced agitation and restlessness
Verbalizes feeling supported and understood

goals.statement: Patient will be linked to appropriate ongoing treatment and support services for substance use disorder
indicators: Verbalizes understanding of addiction as a chronic illness
Expresses motivation for continued treatment
Has a follow-up appointment scheduled with outpatient treatment provider or program
Receives information on mutual support groups (AA, NA, SMART Recovery)

interventions.title: Pharmacological Management of Withdrawal (Symptom-Triggered or Scheduled)
actions: Administer prescribed medications based on withdrawal scale scores and protocols (e.g., benzodiazepines for alcohol/benzo withdrawal; buprenorphine/methadone or alpha-2 agonists for opioid withdrawal).
Monitor withdrawal scores and vital signs regularly (e.g., q1-4h initially, then as clinically indicated).
Adjust medication doses based on patient response and withdrawal severity.
Provide adjunctive medications for specific symptoms (antiemetics for nausea, analgesics for pain, sleep aids).
Educate patient on medications used, purpose, and potential side effects.
rationales: Medications alleviate withdrawal symptoms, prevent complications, and improve comfort.
Regular monitoring guides safe and effective medication titration.
Individualized dosing optimizes symptom control.
Adjunctive medications target specific distressing symptoms.
Education promotes understanding and adherence.
interventions.frequency: Medication per protocol, monitoring frequent and ongoing
specialConsiderations: Be aware of protocols for specific substances (alcohol withdrawal can be life-threatening).
Monitor for oversedation with benzodiazepines.
Ensure appropriate taper schedules if continuing medications post-detox.

interventions.title: Supportive Care and Symptom Management
actions: Provide a calm, quiet, and safe environment; reduce stimuli.
Offer frequent reassurance, emotional support, and validation of patient's experience.
Encourage oral fluids and light, nutritious meals as tolerated; monitor intake and output.
Assist with comfort measures (cool cloths, position changes, quiet activities).
Implement seizure precautions for patients at risk (alcohol, benzodiazepine withdrawal).
rationales: Supportive environment reduces agitation and promotes rest.
Empathy and support reduce distress and build therapeutic alliance.
Hydration and nutrition support physiological recovery.
Comfort measures alleviate physical discomfort.
Seizure precautions ensure safety if seizures occur.
interventions.frequency: Ongoing, tailored to patient needs
specialConsiderations: Reorient frequently if confused or delirious.
Maintain non-judgmental attitude.

interventions.title: Safety Monitoring and Intervention
actions: Monitor for signs of severe or complicated withdrawal (hallucinations, delirium, seizures, severe autonomic instability).
Implement 1:1 observation or increased monitoring if patient is agitated, disoriented, or at high risk for self-harm.
Assess for and address suicidal ideation promptly.
Maintain a hazard-free environment.
Collaborate with medical team for urgent intervention if severe complications arise.
rationales: Early detection of complications allows for rapid intervention.
Increased observation ensures safety for high-risk patients.
Suicide risk can be elevated during withdrawal.
Safe environment prevents accidental injury.
Team approach needed for managing severe complications.
interventions.frequency: Continuous monitoring, especially during peak withdrawal
specialConsiderations: Delirium Tremens (DTs) in alcohol withdrawal is a medical emergency.
Be aware of potential for aggression if patient is agitated or paranoid.

interventions.title: Psychoeducation and Discharge Planning
actions: Provide education about addiction as a chronic brain disease and the nature of withdrawal.
Discuss relapse prevention strategies and coping skills for cravings.
Explore patient's motivation and readiness for change (e.g., using motivational interviewing techniques).
Facilitate referrals to ongoing treatment (inpatient rehab, outpatient counseling, medication-assisted treatment - MAT).
Provide information on community support groups (AA, NA, SMART Recovery) and involve family/supports with patient consent.
rationales: Education reduces stigma and promotes understanding.
Relapse prevention skills are crucial for long-term recovery.
Motivational interviewing enhances intrinsic motivation for change.
Withdrawal management is only the first step; ongoing treatment is essential.
Support groups and family involvement improve recovery outcomes.
interventions.frequency: Throughout stay, with focused discharge planning sessions
specialConsiderations: Address barriers to accessing ongoing treatment (transportation, cost, childcare).
Provide naloxone kit and education for opioid withdrawal patients upon discharge.

evaluations.statement: Is withdrawal managed safely and effectively?
expectedOutcomes: Withdrawal scores remain in mild to moderate range or decrease progressively.
Vital signs stable.
No seizures, delirium, or other severe complications experienced.
Patient reports manageable level of discomfort.
evaluationMethods: Regular withdrawal scale assessments (CIWA, COWS, etc.).

evaluations.statement: Is patient physiologically stable and comfortable?
expectedOutcomes: Adequate hydration and nutritional intake.
Able to rest and sleep.
Reports decreased anxiety, agitation, and physical discomfort.
Oriented to person, place, and time (or return to baseline).
evaluationMethods: Observation of sleep patterns and activity level.
Patient report of comfort and symptoms.

evaluations.statement: Is patient engaged in planning for ongoing recovery?
expectedOutcomes: Patient verbalizes understanding of need for continued treatment.
Participates in discharge planning process.
Accepts referrals for ongoing care.
Expresses hope or motivation for recovery.
evaluationMethods: Patient interview and discussion of treatment goals.
Review of discharge plan and follow-up appointments.
Observation of engagement with psychoeducational content.

notes: Withdrawal management protocols vary based on substance, severity of dependence, and patient comorbidities. Always follow evidence-based guidelines and institutional protocols. A non-judgmental, empathetic approach is crucial. Safety is the top priority.
timeFrame: Acute withdrawal 3-10 days, but stabilization may take longer.
